title: GATT vs. Goniotomy: Navigating the Angle
summary: An exhaustive comparative guide between Gonioscopy-Assisted Transluminal Trabeculotomy (GATT) and traditional Goniotomy. Both are ab-interno MIGS procedures designed to reduce intraocular pressure by targeting the trabecular meshwork.

sections.title: The GATT Process
content: Step 1: Create temporal paracentesis and tilt microscope/head for gonioscopic view.
Step 2: Inject viscoelastic to maintain the anterior chamber and open the angle.
Step 3: Create a small goniotomy incision to access Schlemm's canal.
Step 4: Thread a microcatheter or blunted suture 360 degrees around the canal.
Step 5: Externalize the distal end and pull to rupture the trabecular meshwork circumferentially.

sections.title: The Goniotomy Process
content: Step 1: Position the patient and microscope for optimal gonioscopic visualization.
Step 2: Enter the eye through a clear corneal incision temporal to the target site.
Step 3: Advance the blade (e.g., Kahook Dual Blade) across the AC to the nasal angle.
Step 4: Engage the trabecular meshwork and create a focal incision (scoring).
Step 5: If using a dual-blade, remove a strip of TM tissue to prevent leaflets from closing.

sections.title: Surgical Red Flags
content: Poor visualization of the angle (Corneal edema/opacity)
Neovascular Glaucoma (Risk of massive hyphema)
Extensive Peripheral Anterior Synechiae (PAS)
Active Uveitis or inflammatory glaucoma flare
Uncontrolled episcleral venous pressure

sections.title: Key Advantages: GATT
content: Maximizes outflow facility by treating the entire 360 circumference.
Effective in both primary and secondary open-angle glaucomas.
Can be performed as a standalone or combined with cataract surgery.
Cost-effective if using a 5-0 Prolene suture technique.

sections.title: Key Advantages: Goniotomy
content: Significantly shorter learning curve compared to GATT.
Reduced intraoperative time; less manipulation of the canal.
Lower risk of 'losing' the catheter/suture within the canal.
Proven track record in pediatric/congenital glaucoma cases.

sections.title: Post-Operative Considerations
sections.content: In both GATT and Goniotomy, the most common post-operative finding is a transient hyphema, which usually resolves within 1-2 weeks. Patients are typically started on a regimen of topical steroids and antibiotics. Pilocarpine may be used in some cases to keep the angle open and prevent the formation of synechiae. Success is defined by the reduction of intraocular pressure and the decrease in the number of required glaucoma medications.
